posts.name: ahuang
posts.cooked:
We just updated robotpy to 2025 version using py -m pip install --upgrade robotpy When we try to use: py -m robotpy sync command we get 'robotpy’ is a package and cannot be directly executed.

We have tried py -m pip uninstall “robotpy[all]” and then py -m pip install --upgrade “robotpy[all]” with no luck.

This is the link I have tried to follow: . main ; “robotpy” is a package and cannot be directly executed

How do I resolve this error?

link_counts.title: .__main__; 'robotpy' is a package and cannot be directly executed

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: I don’t think you can —upgrade all for packages you just uninstalled. Theoretically, if you reinstall everything now you should have the most up to date versions of everything right?

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: What version of Python do you have installed, and what is the output of py -m pip list ?

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Also, if you have a directory (edit: or file) named ‘robotpy’ in your robot code, then you’ll get this error. If this is the case, rename that directory to anything else.

posts.name: ahuang
posts.cooked: We have a file named ‘robotpy’, but we don’t think we have a directory named ‘robotpy’

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: If the file is named robotpy (and not robot.py ) then deleting or renaming it will resolve the issue.

posts.name: ahuang
posts.cooked: I just tried renaming the file to robotpy, then back to robot.py but it did not resolve this issue. Do you have any other ideas?

posts.name: ahuang
posts.cooked:
We have robotpy version 2025.2.1.0 installed. I don’t see any version of python though. Here’s the list: Package                  Version

bcrypt                   4.1.2 cffi                     1.16.0 click                    8.1.8 colorama                 0.4.6 cryptography             42.0.5 flexcache                0.3 flexparser               0.4 iniconfig                2.0.0 msvc_runtime             14.42.34433 numpy                    2.2.1 packaging                23.2 paramiko                 3.4.0 phoenix6                 24.2.0 Pint                     0.24.4 pip                      24.3.1 platformdirs             4.3.6 pluggy                   1.4.0 pycparser                2.21 pyfrc                    2025.0.0 PyNaCl                   1.5.0 pynetconsole             2.0.4 pyntcore                 2025.2.1 pytest                   8.0.2 pytest-reraise           2.1.2 robotpy                  2025.2.1.0 robotpy-apriltag         2025.2.1 robotpy-cli              2024.0.0 robotpy-commands-v2      2025.1.1 robotpy-cscore           2025.2.1 robotpy-ctre             2024.1.2 robotpy-hal              2025.2.1 robotpy-halsim-ds-socket 2025.2.1 robotpy-halsim-gui       2025.2.1 robotpy-halsim-ws        2025.2.1 robotpy-installer        2025.0.0 robotpy-navx             2025.0.1 robotpy-pathplannerlib   2025.2.1.post1 robotpy-rev              2025.0.1 robotpy-romi             2025.2.1 robotpy-wpilib-utilities 2025.0.0 robotpy-wpimath          2025.2.1 robotpy-wpinet           2025.2.1 robotpy-wpiutil          2025.2.1 robotpy-xrp              2025.2.1 schedule                 1.2.1 setuptools               65.5.0 tomli                    2.0.1 tomlkit                  0.12.4 typing_extensions        4.10.0 wpilib                   2025.2.1

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
To get the version of python, you can run py --version .

It sounds like you have some kind of environmental conflict – do you have multiple versions of python installed? Try running these commands:

Running the robotpy command from an empty directory should resolve the issue.

If that doesn’t work, check python -m pip list to ensure that robotpy-cli is installed.

Another way you could test is to find the python scripts directory, and run robotpy.exe directly.

posts.name: ahuang
posts.cooked: Thank you for your help! We uninstalled and then reinstalled robotpy-cli and now it works!

mkdir foo
cd foo
py -m robotpy --help
